Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion Chinese Academy of Sciences No.2 Nengyuan Road, Tianhe District Guangzhou 510640 China γ-valerolactone (GVL) is a sustainable chemical, which can be obtained by hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) and levulinate. Herein, we reported a solvent-free hydrogenation of butyl levulinate (BL) to GVL and 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO) over a skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst. The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst was prepared from Devarda's alloy by alkali leaching and the catalyst was characterized by different analysis methods. The aluminum in the Devarda's alloy was dissolved by sodium hydroxide in the leaching process and many active Cu atoms were generated on the catalyst surface and the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn exhibited many micrometer-scale irregular particles with rough surface. The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst showed the excellent performance in the solvent-free hydrogenation of BL to GVL under constant hydrogen pressure (5 wt% catalyst loading, 180°C, 6 MPa of H2, 6 h): the LA conversion was 100%, the GVL yield was 74.75% and the 1,4-PDO yield was 25.63%. Moreover, the catalyst showed stable performance and it was reusable up to 5 times without apparent loss of activity. A stable hydrogen pressure with Zn would suppressed the dehydration of 1,4-PDO. Graphical abstract Butyl levulinate (BL) was efficiently converted into γ-valerolactone (GVL) and 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO) through solvent-free hydrogenation over stable skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalysts with stable activity. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Butyl levulinate Solvent-free hydrogenation γ-valerolactone Skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalysts Abbreviations LA levulinic acid GVL γ-valerolactone BL butyl levulinate 1,4-PDO 1,4-pentanediol 2-MTHF 2-methyltetrahydrofuran n-BuOH n-Butyl alcohol Data availability The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Urged by soaring fossil fuels prices and global warming, lignocellulose as a renewable resources to obtain sustainable fine chemicals and fuels has attracted increasingly attention in recent years. Cellulose is the major component in different lignocellulose, such as agricultural waste (straw, bagasse etc.), forest waste and animal manure. Cellulose can be converted into different platform compounds by chemocatalytic or biocatalytic processing [1]. LA is a main controlled acid-hydrolysis product of the cellulose, and it is also an important bio-based platform compound [2,3]. LA can be transformed to various value-added bio-based chemicals such as levulinate esters, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF), GVL and 1,4-PDO. GVL is an important chemical and can be widely employed as a food or fuel additive, solvent and bulk polymers [4–7]. GVL is prepared from LA or its esters by the catalytic hydrogenation methods [8,9]. The catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA including noble metal catalysts [10] and non-noble metal catalysts, such as Pt-ZrO2, Ru-Mo/AC, Co/SiO2, Ni/SiO2 and Cu/Al2O3 catalysts etc. [11–13]. Generally, noble metal catalysts have higher catalytic activity than non-noble metal catalysts [14,15]. Xu et al. found that 90% yield of GVL from LA solution (LA/H2O or LA/dioxane, 10 wt%) could be obtained over Pd-Ru bimetallic catalyst at 65°C [16]. Cui et al. reported that 96.7 mol% yield of 1,4-PDO was obtained over Ru-MoOx/activated carbon catalyst for the hydrogenation of LA solution (LA/H2O=5 wt%) to 1,4-PDO [12]. However, the noble metal-based catalysts have some drawbacks, such as recovery difficulty and high cost, thus they are not preferable for large-scale application in the industry. The development of non-noble metal-based catalysts with high catalytic activity may provide a potential solution to solve these problems. They showed excellent catalytic property in the hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds and hydrogenation of LA and levulinate [17,18]. Sun et al. investigated the vapor-phase hydrogenation of methyl levulinate and LA to GVL over different catalysts (Co/SiO2, Ni/SiO2 and Cu/Al2O3) using a fixed-bed reactor with a liquid feed rate of 1.65 g/h [13]. The results indicated that the Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibited the highest GVL yield (85.7%) in LA hydrogenation. Pinto et al. found that Ni–Mo/C catalysts shows a good activity for the direct hydrogenation of LA solution (LA/H2O=10 wt%) to high-yield (95%) of GVL under mild reaction conditions (100°C, 2 h, 100 bar H2) [19]. Recently, Ren et al. reported a ternary skeletal Cu-Al-Zn as catalyst to achieve high yields of 1,4-PDO from levulinate esters solution (ethyl levulinate/dioxane, 1/144 g/mL) [20]. They pointed out that the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst has some advantages including excellent reusability, simple preparation and low cost. Although there are lots of researches on the direct hydrogenation of LA or its esters solution to GVL or 1,4-PDO, only a few researches focused on the solvent-free catalysis condition. Generally, the solvent catalysis system usually associated with the high cost, toxicity of the organic solvents due to reaction requires a large amount solvent. Instead, the solvent-free catalysis system can greatly facilitate the productivity improvement and separation of the products. Moreover, in terms of economic and environmental, solvent-free catalysis condition seems to be a more appealing reaction system for the preparation of GVL due to its production efficiency and energy-efficient separation compared to solvent catalysis system which the amounts of LA or its ester in the feedstock is only 1-5 wt% [21]. The homogeneous nickel-phosphine complex [22] and homogeneous Ru(acac)3/PnOct3 [23] catalyst can convert LA to GVL in a solvent-free condition with the high yield. Although these homogeneous catalysts can achieve high conversion rate and yield, many drawbacks including catalysts separation, recovery and recycling of the catalyst limit their further applications. Some heterogeneous non-noble metal-based catalysts for LA to GVL, such as Ni-Cu (Ni-Co, Cu-Co)/Al2O3 nanofibers catalyst [24], Ni–MoOx/carbon catalyst [25], by the solvent-free method were reported. However, these catalysts had different problems such as complex preparation and cost support. In this work, the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn was used as catalyst for the synthesis of GVL from butyl levulinate (BL) under solvent-free condition. The catalyst was characterized by different analysis methods. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials BL (98%) and 1,4-PDO (99.9%) are provided by Aladdin reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China); Devarda's alloy (Cu-Al-Zn) and GVL (99.9%) are obtained from Macklin biochemical Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). n-Butyl alcohol (n-BuOH) and ethyl alcohol (EtOH) are provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All reagents were used without any further purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst was prepared according to Ren et al. [20]. Briefly, the Devarda's alloy powder (200 mesh) was treated with 20 wt% NaOH solution for 3.5 h in the ice-water bath. After the reaction time, the product was filtered, washed with deionized water until the pH=7 and stored in ethanol. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The catalysts were digested with concentrated hydrochloric acid and nitric acid first, and then the element composition of the catalysts was determined by the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer, OPTIMA 8000). The catalysts were degassed at 80 °C for 6 h, then the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area (S BET), pore volume (Vp ) and pore diameter (Dp ) of the catalysts were determined by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K in an ASIQMO002-2 analyzer (Quantachrome, USA). The X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were determined using by X-ray diffractometer (X'Pert Pro MPD, PANalytical, Holland) through Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.154 nm, 40 kV and 100 mA), and the scanning range (2θ) was 5°-80°. The catalyst was sputter-coated with gold, and then used an S-4800 (Hitachi) scanning electron microscope (SEM) to observe the morphology of the catalyst. The morphology and EDX mapping analyses of the catalyst was determined by a high resolution field emission transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL). The NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried out on an Automated Chemisorption Analyzer (Chemstar TPX, Quantachrome). The NH3-TPD process as follows: the catalyst (about 50 mg) was activated at 280°C for 30 min in helium atmosphere (30 mL/min), the activated catalyst was exposed in 5% NH3/Ar at 50°Cfor 50 min. Then the sample was rinsed for 15 min with helium flow (30 mL/min). The NH3-TPD was conducted at the temperature range from 100 to 800°C with the temperature rate of 10°C/min in helium atmosphere (30 mL/min). The H2-TPR process as follows: the catalyst (about 50 mg) was activated at 250°C for 1 h in Ar atmosphere (30 mL/min), and then the activated catalyst was heated to 350°C in He flow (30 mL/min) and stayed for 1h at 350°C in oxygen flow (30 mL/min). The H2-TPR was conducted at the temperature range from 100°C to 800°C in H2/Ar flow (30mL/ min, 10°C/min). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was determined on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi equipped with a monochromatic Al-Ka X-ray source. The C 1s signal (284.6 eV) was used as an internal standard for calibration of the XPS signals. The infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-FT-IR) were employed with a Perkin-Elmer Frontier FT-IR. 30 mg of catalyst was pretreated at 350°C for 1 h, and then the pyridine adsorption was carried out at 30°C for 30 min. Subsequently, the FT-IR spectrum was determined after the sample was treated at 350°C for 1 h. 2.4 Activity measurement The hydrogenation setup used in this experiment is shown in Fig. 1 . It consists of two high pressure gas cylinders (H2 and N2), a one-way valve and a 100 mL Parr-type reactor (YZ-PR100) equipped with a stirrer, electrical heating jacket, as well as interior temperature, stirring speed and pressure monitor. For a typical catalytic reaction, BL (30.00g) and certain amount of catalyst powder were introduced into the vessel. Before each run, the vessel was sealed first and the air was removed by flushed with N2 three times and H2 three times. The reactor was heated to the certain temperature with vigorous stirring (600 rpm), and then a prescribed hydrogen pressure was set. After reaction, the mixture was centrifuged to obtain liquid products and recycle catalyst. The recycled catalyst was using deionized water and ethanol in sequence to wash thoroughly, and then reused for the next run. The liquid products were analyzed with a GC 7980A gas chromatograph (Agilent) equipped with capillary column (FFAP, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and flame ionization detector (FID). The BL conversion and product yield were calculated according to Shao et al. [26]. (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = Mole of reactant converted Mole of feedstock × 100 % (2) Y i e l d ( % ) = Mole of targeting material produced Mole of feedstock × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of Devarda's alloy and catalyst are shown in Fig. 1. The pattern of Devarda's alloy exhibited typical diffraction peaks of Cu-Al2 at 2θ=20.64°, 29.38°, 37.91°, 42.6,° 47.33°, 47.80°, 69.20° and 77.24°. After treated by NaOH solution, the characteristic peaks of the Cu-Al2 were disappeared, which indicated that the aluminum in the alloy was dissolved in the leaching process. The pattern of fresh catalyst (skeletal Cu-Al-Zn) exhibited typical sharp peaks of metallic Cu (Cu0) at 43.18° (diffraction plane (111)), 50.3° (diffraction plane (200)) and 74° (diffraction plane (220)) [27]. The diffraction peaks at 35.4° (diffraction plane (002)) and 38.7° (diffraction plane (111)) were assigned to the crystal planes of CuO (JCPDS 45-0937) [28]. The weak diffraction peak at 44.7° was assigned to the characteristic diffraction peak of Al. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Devarda's alloy and fresh catalyst exhibited classic II type isotherm with a H3-hysteresis loop (Fig. 2 ) at a lower relative pressure (P/P0 = 0.05), which indicated that the presence of mesopores. Moreover, the BET surface area of ​​the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst was 46.41 m2/g (Table 1 ) while the BET surface area of Devarda's alloy was 27.29 m2/g. It was obvious that a larger BET surface area of ​​the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst is obtained in the leaching process of the Devarda's alloy due to Al in the Cu-Al alloy phase was dissolved by NaOH, which triggered the formation of Cu atoms on the catalyst surface and increased the active sites numbers for the hydrogenation reaction [20]. The SEM image (Fig. 3 a) showed that skeletal Cu-Al-Zn was composed by many micrometer-scale irregular particles with rough surfaces. The TEM image and EDX mapping analyses of catalyst (Fig. 3b and c) indicated that the Cu, Al and Zn elements are uniformly distributed throughout the whole particles. Furthermore, ICP data showed that the content of Cu element in the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst was 50.92%, which was higher than that of Devarda's alloy (45.47%) (Table 1). On the other hand, the content of Al element in the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst was 12.39%, which were far lower than that of Devarda's alloy (50.77%). Fig. 4 presents the NH3-TPD and H2-TPR profiles of the catalyst. The NH3-TPD curve of the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst (Fig. 4a) exhibits two desorption peaks in the temperature range of 100–800°C, which indicated that there are two types of acid sites in the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst. The Py-FT-IR spectra of the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst are detected between 1400–1700 cm−1 (Fig. 5 b). The peaks at 1446 and 1596 cm−1 were assigned to the hydrogen-bonded L sites, which indicate that existence of Lewis acid sites [29,30]. The weak peak at 1486 cm−1 was attributed to both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [31]. The sharply peak at 1596 cm−1 was attributed to desorption of hydrogen-bonded pyridine. These acid sites facilitate the hydrogenation of the BL to form GVL or 1,4-PDO. The TPR profiles of the skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst (Fig. 4b) showed a sharp single hydrogen consumption peak at about 250–350°C, which was related to the reduction of CuO [32]. To further insight into the surface distribution of elements and chemical state of Cu elements, the catalysts were characterized by XPS. Fig. 5a exhibited that the peaks at binding energies (BE) of 933.52 and 952.58 were attributed to the Cu0 species while the peaks at BE of 935.17 and 954.33 eV were related to the Cu2+ species [27,33–35]. 3.2 BL hydrogenation reaction in the autoclave The effect of hydrogenation reaction conditions including reaction temperature, reaction pressure, reaction time and catalyst dosage on the BL hydrogenation performances are shown in Fig. 6 . The effect of catalyst dosage on the hydrogenation results of BL are shown in Fig. 6a. The catalyst dosage has a large effect on the products conversion. The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn showed outstanding catalytic performance. When the catalyst loading was 0.05 wt%, the BL conversion was 43.377 % and the GVL yield and 1,4-PDO yield were 6.48 and 0.56 %, respectively, under solvent-free conditions. As catalyst loading increased, the BL conversion increased sharply. When the catalyst loading was 1 wt%, the BL conversion was 98.9 % and the GVL yield and 1,4-PDO yield were 54.79 and 7.36 %, respectively. The yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO increased sharply first and then decreased with increase of catalyst dosage. The reason may be that the catalyst was not only to enhance hydrogenation of BL to GVL and hydrogenation of GVL to 1,4-PDO but also to accelerate the other side reaction, and thus the yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO decreased at the high catalyst dosage (12%). The effect of reaction pressure on the hydrogenation of BL to GVL is shown in Fig. 6b. It was obvious that the high pressure can enhance the BL conversion, the BL conversion increased from 90.1 to 98.2 % when the reaction pressure from 1 MPa to 3.5 MPa. Moreover, the 1,4-PDO yield increased with increasing the reaction pressure. In terms of reaction equilibrium, high reaction pressures mean more partial hydrogen that took part in the reaction, and thus could promote the hydrogenation reaction process to reach the equilibrium [36]. The catalyst reaction temperature has a small effect on the hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 6c). When the hydrogenation reaction was carried out at a lower temperature (140°C), only 97.09 % of BL conversion with a GVL yield of 46.31 % was obtained. The BL conversion and GVL yield increased slowly as the temperature increased. When the reaction temperature was 180°C, the maximum BL conversion and GVL yield was 98.20 % and 52.53 %, respectively. It was probable that the process of H2 dissociation on Cu0 sites is endothermic process, higher temperature will accelerate to break through the energy barrier of hydrogen activation [29]. However, a further increase in reaction temperature (200°C), GVL yield and 1,4-PDO yield were decreased but the 2-MTHF yield (0.26%) was increased, which was might be the dehydration of 1,4-PDO to 2-MTHF are promoted at higher reaction temperature. It seems that the reaction time has little effect on the BL conversion but it has a large impact on the products selectivity (Fig. 6d). The GVL yield increased firstly and reached the maximum of 55.12 %, then decreased as the increasing of the reaction time. The trend of the 1,4-PDO yield was also similar to GVL yield. However, further increasing the reaction time could leaded to the obvious decrease the yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO but increased the 2-MTHF yield. Generally, the GVL can be hydrogenated to produce 1,4-PDO which can be further dehydrated to form 2-MTHF. However, Ren et al.[20] and Liu et al. [37] found that the addition of Zn species into Cu based catalyst could not only suppress the dehydration of 1,4-PDO but also enhance the conversion rate of acrylate hydrogenation. The reason may be that the H2 in the reactor was almost complete depletion in later stage reaction, then the dehydration of 1,4-PDO to 2-MTHF was favored. 3.3 BL hydrogenation reaction under constant hydrogen pressure Generally, the amount of H2 is limited under certain pressure in the autoclave, and the H2 pressure decreases as the reaction progress due to the hydrogenation reaction consumes large amounts of H2. In order to eliminate the "H2-poor" adverse effects, the BL hydrogenation reaction under constant hydrogen pressure are carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The H2 pressure was remained constant in the reaction by opening the one-way H2 valve of the reaction system (Fig. 1). The solvent-free hydrogenation process of BL under constant hydrogen pressure was different from conventional solvent-free hydrogenation reaction (limited hydrogen supply) in the autoclave. It was clear that BL was hydrogenated into GVL quickly, and then GVL was further converted into 1,4-PDO (Fig. 7d). It seems that the production of the GVL from BL was fast, but the cleavage of the lactone ring of the GVL to produce 1,4-PDO was difficult and slow. Obviously, supply of continues hydrogen would promote the BL conversion and increased the products yield especially for 1,4-PDO yield under the same reaction conditions. Moreover, the transformation of 1,4-PDO into 2-MTHF might be suppressed to a larger extent under constant hydrogen pressure. The maximum yield of 1,4-PDO was up to 25.63% (Fig. 7b) under constant hydrogen pressure in a technique condition (10 wt% of catalyst loading, 6 MPa of H2, 6 h and 180 °C). It's evident that that sufficient hydrogen will facilitate the cleavage of the lactone ring of the GVL to produce 1,4-PDO. On the other hand, the control experiment of the solvent-free hydrogenation of BL over Devarda's alloy under the same reaction condition (5 wt% of Devarda's alloy loading, 6 MPa of H2, 6 h and 180 °C) were also carried out and the conversion of BL was only 32.08% and the GVL selectivity was 39.59%. This result suggested that skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst is more suitable to hydrogenation of BL than Devarda's alloy. A summary on solvent-free hydrogenation of LA or its ester to GVL or 1,4-PDO is listed in Table 2 . Homogeneous catalysts showed the high LA conversion and product selectivity for the solvent-free hydrogenation of LA but complicated ligands and poor recoverability limited its application. As to heterogeneous catalysts, noble metal catalysts exhibited higher catalytic activity than non-noble metal catalysts. Bucciol et al. reported that 100% of the 1,4-PDO yield was obtained over Au/TiO2 [38] catalyst for the solvent-free hydrogenation of LA. Liu et al. [39] found that the hydrogen bond between LA and choline chloride can enhance the adsorption of the acyl group of LA over Ru/C. For the hydrogenation of pure LA, the LA conversion of 39.7% was achieved with a GVL yield of 36.5% over Ru/C while the LA conversion was sharply increased (99.5%) when 10 wt% choline chloride was introduced. In terms of solvent-free hydrogenation of LA over non- noble metal catalysts, CuCr [40] provided a GVL yield of 95%, much less than that of skeletal Cu-Zn-Al in this study. Thus, skeletal Cu-Zn-Al was an attractive catalyst for the solvent-free hydrogenation of LA or ethyl levulinate to GVL or 1,4-PDO. In order to investigate the pathways for the hydrogenation of BL, some control experiments using GVL as a starting reactant were carried out under same experimental conditions (Fig. 8 ). In comparison with the hydrogenation of the BL, the reaction time has a large impact on the GVL conversion and 1,4-PDO yield under solvent-free condition, and the GVL conversion and 1,4-PDO yield increased with the increase of reaction time. A 49.39% GVL conversion with 37.12% of 1,4-PDO yield was obtained for the hydrogenation of GVL (5 wt% of catalyst loading, 6 MPa of H2, 6 h and 180°C), while a complete conversion (100%) with the 17.87% of 1,4-PDO yield for the hydrogenation of the BL over the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst in 6 h. This was further confirmed that the production of the GVL from BL was relatively easy, but the cleavage of the lactone ring of the GVL to produce 1,4-PDO was difficult. Thus, as shown in Scheme 2, a possible reaction pathway for hydrogenation of BL to 1,4-PDO over skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst might by proposed as followed [41]: the BL was first transformed into GVL by hydrogenation, and then GVL further converted to 1,4-PDO. The high-activity skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst extremely facilitated the BL rapid conversion to GVL while the hydrogenation of GVL to 1,4-PDO was a bit difficult and slow under solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, a stable hydrogen pressure with Zn on the catalyst surface would suppressed the dehydration of 1,4-PDO to 2-MTHF [37]. 3.4 Catalyst recyclability test The results of the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst recyclability tests for the hydrogenation of BL are shown in Fig. 9 . After each cycle, the used catalyst was separated from solution by filtration. The filter residue was washed with absolute ethanol, dried and applied in the next run. The BL conversion was almost 100 % in five runs, and the yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO was decreased slightly after five successive cycles. The GVL yield and 1,4-PDO yield was 74.75 and 27.7%, respectively, in the first run, while the yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO was 69.95% and 24.87% after five successive runs. However, the yields of GVL (38.04%) and 1,4-PDO (11.17%) was decreased sharply while the BL conversion remained constant in the sixth run. The decrease in yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO in 6th run was due to the surface of catalyst was oxidation in the recycle process (Fig. 5a). The spent catalyst was recovered in a quartz tube furnace (400°C, 2h, 30 mL/min of H2 flow rate). The regenerated catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity for the BL hydrogenation (Fig. 9, run 7 and run 8), the yields of GVL and 1,4-PDO over the regenerated catalyst was 66.24 and 20.53% (Fig. 9, run 8 ). The spent catalyst was further investigated for better understanding of deactivation mechanism of catalyst. The EDX mapping analyses of spent catalyst showed that an Al-Zn alloy may be formed in catalyst which can be used as carrier for Cu species (Fig. 10 ). ICP result showed that Cu content and Al content in the spent catalyst were 48.98% and 12.39%, respectively, which was lower than that of fresh one (50.92 and 8.15%) (Table 1). This indicated that a small amount of Cu and Al species might be leached from skeletal Cu-Zn-Al catalyst during the reaction. Moreover, the XRD pattern of spent catalyst exhibited additional diffraction peak at 36.3° was assigned to the diffraction peak of CuO2 [42] (Fig. 1), which indicated that the surface of catalyst was oxidation in the recovery process. Moreover, the intensity of Cu2+ peaks at 954.37 and 933.98 eV for spent catalyst in the XPS spectra were enhanced compare to fresh catalysts (Fig. 5a). After the regeneration, the diffraction peak of CuO2 was disappeared in the XRD pattern of regenerated catalyst (Fig. 1) and the small Cu2+ peak at 934.25 eV was detected in the XPS spectra for Cu 2p of regenerated catalyst (Fig. 5a), which indicated that the CuO2 was completely reduced . Therefore, there are two main reasons for the deactivation of catalyst: one is the surface of catalyst was oxidized in the recycle process, the other is the leaching of Cu species from the catalyst. 4 Conclusion Devarda's alloy powder was treated with NaOH solution to obtain the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn, which was used as catalyst for the synthesis of GVL from BL under solvent-free condition. The XRD patterns, ICP-OES and SEM results indicated that the Al in the Devarda's alloy was dissolved by the NaOH in the leaching process to form skeletal Cu-Al-Zn that was composed many micrometer-scale irregular particles with rough surfaces and many active Cu atoms were formation on the catalyst surface. The highest GVL yield of 74.75% and 1,4-PDO yield was 25.63% with LA conversion of 100% were achieved at 180°C and 6 MPa of constant hydrogen pressure after 6 h. Moreover, catalyst showed stable performance and it was reusable up to five times without significant loss of activity. The catalysts deactivation might be caused by surface oxidation in the recycle process and the leaching of Cu species in the reaction. The spent catalyst could by regenerated by thermal reduction. The overall hydrogenation of BL to 1,4-PDO was believed to proceed through hydrogenation converted to GVL and then further transformed into 1,4-PDO by hydrogenation (Scheme 1). coredata.dc:description: γ-valerolactone (GVL) is a sustainable chemical, which can be obtained by hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) and levulinate. Herein, we reported a solvent-free hydrogenation of butyl levulinate (BL) to GVL and 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO) over a skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst. The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst was prepared from Devarda's alloy by alkali leaching and the catalyst was characterized by different analysis methods. The aluminum in the Devarda's alloy was dissolved by sodium hydroxide in the leaching process and many active Cu atoms were generated on the catalyst surface and the skeletal Cu-Al-Zn exhibited many micrometer-scale irregular particles with rough surface. The skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst showed the excellent performance in the solvent-free hydrogenation of BL to GVL under constant hydrogen pressure (5 wt% catalyst loading, 180°C, 6 MPa of H2, 6 h): the LA conversion was 100%, the GVL yield was 74.75% and the 1,4-PDO yield was 25.63%. Moreover, the catalyst showed stable performance and it was reusable up to 5 times without apparent loss of activity. A stable hydrogen pressure with Zn would suppressed the dehydration of 1,4-PDO.
coredata.dc:title: The solvent-free hydrogenation of butyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone and 1,4-pentanediol over skeletal Cu-Al-Zn catalyst
